author: Patrick

review: I enjoy my Google Chromecast. I wish it worked with my Amazon Prime Movies. Right now it is very limited, YouTube and Netflix. I hope there is more support soon. The one thing I noticed is it gets pretty warm for it's size. Because of this I got out my trusty Kill A Watt (TM) device and measured the power consumption. When it's power cube is connected the Chromecast consumes 4 watts of power. This is true whether it is connected to your television or not. If you unplug it from the power cable, the power cube shows no power consumption. Because this device will get limited use for now, I will be unplugging it except when I want to use it. It only takes a few seconds to start up when power is applied.I also have a Roku box and it's power consumption is 6 watts. As with the Chormecast, there is no power switch so it is consuming power whether you are watching on it or not.There is so much great programming on YouTube I feel my money was well spent. The video quality is excellent. I have no complaints with the product so far. With more support, I would give it five stars.

review: It's not very trivial to set it up but once it's up it works great. Google's instruction did not say that when it's first powered on, the Chromecast runs as its own wifi network that I had to change my laptop's wifi to connect to its network SSID in order to set up my home network on the chromecast itself. After it's done then I had to change my laptop back to my home network.

review: I was initially favorably impressed with the relatively easy setup and the playback of a number of YouTube videos. This device handles the older simpler videos on YouTube quite capably. However, when I tried to play the official YouTube video for When In Rome, "The Promise", the Chromecast device simply did not have the adequate horsepower to launch the video after the advertisement.As a test, I then switched to my Chromebox, which is hooked up to my TV on another HDMI slot, and played the When In Rome video FLAWLESSLY. Well, you can't really compare a $35 Chromecast with a $400 Chromebox, as there obviously is a whole order of magnitude difference between these two platforms both on a technical and price dimension.I will take this device with me when on travel, and try it out on the TVs in the hotel rooms just to see how successful I am with the free Wifi that comes with the room. It's a cool gadget. I don't know how well it works with the Netflix and Hulu Plus apps, so you will have to read the other reviews for these options. Perhaps there will be a software upgrade in the future that will mitigate the specific issue I had with it.
